goals.question: What is the trend of electricity consumption in Iowa over the years?
goals.visualization: Line chart of electricity consumption over time
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there is an increase or decrease in electricity consumption in Iowa over the years.

goals.question: What is the distribution of residential electricity consumption in Iowa?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the range and frequency of residential electricity consumption in Iowa.

goals.question: What is the correlation between commercial and industrial electricity consumption in Iowa?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of commercial and industrial electricity consumption
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there is a positive or negative correlation between commercial and industrial electricity consumption in Iowa.

goals.question: What is the average electricity consumption per capita in Iowa?
goals.visualization: Bar chart of electricity consumption per capita
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the average electricity consumption per person in Iowa.

goals.question: What is the distribution of electricity rates in Iowa?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the range and distribution of electricity rates in Iowa.

code:
```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('iowa-electricity.csv')

# Convert date field to date type
data['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['Date'], format='%Y-%m-%d', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['Date'])]

# Line chart of electricity consumption over time
sns.set_style("darkgrid")
sns.lineplot(x="Date", y="Consumption", data=data, color='blue')

# Set chart title
plt.title("What is the trend of electricity consumption in Iowa over the years?", wrap=True)

# Rotate x-axis labels for legibility
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Show plot
plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('iowa-electricity.csv')

# Plot histogram of residential electricity consumption
sns.histplot(data=data, x='residential', kde=True, color='blue')
plt.axvline(data['residential'].mean(), color='red', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=1, label='Mean')
plt.axvline(data['residential'].median(), color='green', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=1, label='Median')
plt.legend()
plt.title('What is the distribution of residential electricity consumption in Iowa?')
plt.xlabel('Residential Electricity Consumption (kWh)')
plt.ylabel('Frequency')

plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('iowa-electricity.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['Date'], format='%Y-%m-%d', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['Date'])]

# Create scatter plot
sns.scatterplot(x='Commercial', y='Industrial', data=data)

# Set chart title
plt.title('What is the correlation between commercial and industrial electricity consumption in Iowa?', wrap=True)

# Add correlation line
corr = data['Commercial'].corr(data['Industrial'])
plt.axline(xy1=(0, 0), slope=corr, color='red', label=f'Correlation: {corr:.2f}')

# Add legend
plt.legend()

# Show plot
plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('iowa-electricity.csv')

# Calculate electricity consumption per capita
data['consumption_per_capita'] = data['Total Retail Sales']/data['Population']

# Create bar chart
sns.barplot(x='Year', y='consumption_per_capita', data=data, color='blue')

# Set chart title and axis labels
plt.title('What is the average electricity consumption per capita in Iowa?')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Electricity consumption per capita (kWh)')

# Add horizontal line for average consumption
avg_consumption = data['consumption_per_capita'].mean()
plt.axhline(y=avg_consumption, color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Average consumption: {avg_consumption:.2f} kWh')

# Add legend
plt.legend()

# Rotate x-axis labels for legibility
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Show plot
plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('iowa-electricity.csv')

# Plot
sns.set(style="whitegrid")
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.boxplot(x="year", y="price", data=data, ax=ax, palette="Set3")
ax.set_title("What is the distribution of electricity rates in Iowa?")
ax.set_xlabel("Year")
ax.set_ylabel("Electricity Rate ($/kWh)")
plt.show()
```
